author: Jasper Hamill
title: NASA has found water on Mars - could alien life be the next great discovery?
text:
The sort of life we might find on Mars is unlikely to take the form of little green men.
But finding even the tiniest scrap of microbial life on the barren surface of the Red Planet will permanently change the way we humans view our place in the universe.
Today, NASA announced the discovery of liquid water on Mars and said there was a "high chance" of discovering alien lifeforms buried beneath the Martian surface.
It even said manned missions could use this water to produce rocket fuel, grow food and sustain astronauts whilst they explore the distant planet.
Here's your guide to the latest astonishing NASA discoveries and their significance in the search for extraterrestrial life.
What has NASA found? Nasa have claimed that there is flowing water almost certainly on Mars
The space agency discovered salty water on the surface of Mars.
Using the Mars Reconnaisance Orbiter, NASA spotted evidence of salts which could only have been deposited by water.
Sadly, the craft only peers at the Martian surface at 3pm each day, meaning any liquid water would have evaporated.
Will we find more water on Mars? NASA/JPL/University of Arizona/Handout These dark streaks are thought to have been formed by running water
Perhaps. It It is thought that Mars was once home to a massive ocean which was "as big as two thirds of Earth's northern hemisphere" and at least a mile deep.
It is thought this disappeared during a period of massive climate change, evaporating into space.
There may also be underground aquifers, although this cannot be established yet.
Is there life on Mars? NASA A mock-up of a Martian Stonehenge (which doesn't exist)
Again, we don't know for sure yet.
Alfred McEwen, professor of planetary geology at the University of Arizona, said: "The possibility of finding life in in the interior of Mars is very high."
However, this could just be life from Earth, because microbes may have hitched a ride aboard a meteorite from earth.
What does the discovery of water mean for human space missions? NASA/JPL/University of Arizona/PA Scientists believe that flowing liquid water is almost certainly responsible for mysterious features on Mars that change with the seasons
Quite a lot, because astronauts could not only drink the water, but use it to make Mars more habitable.
NASA suggested it could be used in greenhouses where the plants feast off the Martian carbon dioxide and turn it into oxygen.
Water could "may decrease the cost and increase the resilience of human activity on the Red Planet," said Mary Beth Wilhelm from NASA's Ames Research Centre.
